text: Thank you so much to Lakshmi, Robin,

and everyone who has helped
make this event so wonderful.
It is great to be here.
My name is Danya Lagos,

and I am here to present
some of the research
that I've been working on
about this question of has there been
a transgender tipping point?
So, it is commonly known that attitudes
and opportunities related to gender

and what gender means
can change over time.

However, what I'm asking
in today's presentation
is can patterns of social change
shift the distribution of gender itself?

In the mid-2010s, there
was a media narrative

in magazines like "Time,"
"National Geographic,"

"The New York Times" suggesting
that American society
and other societies within its orbits
had reached a transgender tipping point.

And actress Laverne Cox
was quoted as saying,
"We are getting to a point in time
where more and more people are saying,
'This is who I am, I am transgender.'"

And so it is a claim about not
only increased civil rights,
increased media visibility,
but also increased prevalence of a way
of identifying with gender.
So this leads us to a question

of does an increase in
visibility and civil rights

also lead to an increase
in the number of people
who come to identify as transgender?
And here this question might echo
the question posed by John D'Emilio

in his 1983 essay,
"Capitalism and Gay Identity"
where he argued that over time,

the conditions of capitalism
were actually responsible
for creating a series of opportunities

for people to come to identify
as gay that were not--
or gay and lesbian,

and that were not possible
in pre-capitalist societies,
and that that reality came
not with a condemnation of gay identity,

but as a series of radical
opportunities to then take this
and forge bonds of solidarity
and realize the material underpinnings
of sexual life and sexual rights.

This narrative hits a
few snags along the way.

So over time in arguments
made before the Supreme Court
as with the Obergefell case,

an assumption was made in
the claims about civil rights

that sexual and gender
minorities are born this way.

That being gay or lesbian
or bisexual or transgender
or queer in some way is a trait

that is randomly
distributed in populations.
Now this claim while successful

and leveraged by many
mainstream LGBT organizations

caught the attention of
anti-trans activists,
people who would seek to exclude
transgender people from public life,
and they used their perceptions

which was at odds of
this random distribution.

They made the claim well, it
doesn't seem random to me.
They used the perceived increase
in trans identification in recent cohorts
and they're saying well, if it's
more present in younger cohorts,

this does not seem like a
random distribution to me.
And in recent books published
by anti-trans activist, Abigail Shrier,
she even points to a specific issue,
that transgender identity is a craze

using the language of
pandemics and epidemics
that young children are being,

that she refers to this
flight from womanhood
that is particularly attracting people

who are assigned female at
birth to identify as trans men
because being a woman is stigmatized.
So she points to what she perceives
as it mainly being a surge among people
assigned female at birth to suggest

well, this is not seeming like
a random distribution to me.
So in addition to discriminating
against people who are trans,
a shift recently as civil rights law
has changed and adapted,
a goal has shifted to preventing people
from becoming trans in the first place

if it's not as easy
anymore to discriminate
against trans people directly.

So here are some concepts
that I'm going to use
to talk about what we're looking at here.
I'm going to borrow from Doug McAdam's
concept of biographical availability

and this refers to the absence
of personal constraints
that may increase the costs
and risks of movement participation,
and his research was focused
mainly on the Freedom Summer in the 1960s.
So what attracted young people to go

and participate in the
Freedom Summer riots
and he found that gender, having children
put people in a particular position
that made it harder or participate--

Victor mentioned things that
make activism much harder,

as a parent, as an academic on
the tenure track, et cetera.
So this is the concept
that I'm referring to throughout the talk,
and I want to distinguish here
between identity and identification.

So identity being an
attribute that is present

or inscribed in individuals
as they navigate in society
versus identification which is an aspect

of individuals' senses of
self that can be activated
or negotiated within historical, material,

and social context of
opportunity and constraint.
So even people who are not born
Americans become sometimes Americans

and so this is a process
of be identification.
It is not simply present in someone
and is observed by other people.
So the data that I work with come from

the CDC's Behavioral Risk
Factor Surveillance System

given the very attractive
name BRFSS sometimes.
(audience laughs)
And the BRFSS started collecting in 2014.
It started asking people

a flawed but important
question, are you transgender?
And if people answered yes,

they would then get asked
another series of questions,

which was do you identify
as female-to-male,
male-to-female, or gender-nonconforming?

And they had to choose
one of these options.

Now, this is not how I
would've designed the survey,

but it still provides us
something to work with.

And so over the 2014
and 2019 administrations
of the data that I'm working with,
there are 39 states in the United States
that have provided this question,
because it's administered by the states
as part of a federal effort.

And so, while there are
some notable absences,

I do think that there's a
wide distribution of states
in terms of political composition,
in terms of racial-ethnic composition,
in terms of what their labor markets
might look like, et cetera.
And so this yielded a pretty good sample

of 4,604 transgender and
gender-nonconforming respondents,

but it also allowed us a
comparably recruited sample
in over 800,000 respondents.
But I want to talk a little bit,
I want to step back from the data

and put us in the context
of how transgender history
has unfolded in the United States.

So there have been people
who have identified

with a variety of identities
that are not understood
as cisgender today throughout US history,

but these are some of the
main inflection points
that historians like Susan Stryker
and Jules Gill-Peterson have identified,
and C. Riley Snorton as well.

So in 1952 this was considered
the first big media sensation
about a transgender person.
Christine Jorgenson made sex change
a household term at the time.
There was also this riot in San Francisco
which was a precursor of Stonewall
that was primarily working class people,
including working class people of color,

who were being harassed at
their hangout spot by the police
and decided to fight back.
In 1973, so in this post-Stonewall moment,
there was a schism between trans activists

and the gay liberation movement
and the women's movements
including activists like Sylvia Rivera
being prevented from speaking
at the 1973 Christopher Street parade
which was the main precursor
to Pride events as we know them now.

And then in 1993 there
was a high profile murder
of a person named Brandon Teena,
which, within the community
of lesbians and transgender men

created what was known
then as the Border Wars.

Another event that I
want to call attention to

is the events of 9-11 which
provoked a huge increase
in the importance of legal documents

and the foundation of legal
efforts to make it more possible

for transgender people to
change legal documents.
So what is this history
that I've outlined here very loosely mean?

I have data from people
born from 1935 through 2001,
because it was a survey of US adults,

and they stopped measuring
age at 80 unfortunately,

but they also only measured
people who were 18 and older.

And so here I want to
walk us through loosely
the ages that people would've been
at the time of these events
because I think it's important.

So someone born in this
initial cohort here

when Christine Jorgenson's
name became a household name,
they would've been around 10 years old.

Someone born in 1945
would've been a child,
but maybe their parents
would have heard of Christine Jorgenson
and they would've been coming of age
at around the Compton's Cafeteria riot,
would've been in their 20s

during the rupture with
gay and lesbian movements.
They would've been in their 30s
at the beginning of the AIDS pandemic.
So these are all events--

for brevity I'm not going
through them one by one,

but as we see people
experience time differently
depending on when they were alive.

So, I have a few theories
about what might look different

in terms of are there
generational differences?
And so here's one theory.

If we take the narrative that
there is a arc of history

but it is bending ever
slowly towards justice,

perhaps it will be a linear
increase in social acceptance,
which will lead over time to more people

slowly identifying as
trans once the conditions

of the closet and expected
cis-normativity are eased.

So one could expect that this
would be a linear change.

Another theory, so the data
do permit us to distinguish

between people who identify
as trans men, as trans women,
and as gender-nonconforming.

Very unfortunately there
is not a lot of nuance.

There is a lot of overlap
between these categories.
Not everyone who is a transgender man
or is a transgender woman

would characterize themselves
as gender-conforming.

But these are the categories
that the CDC collected,
and that is what I'm working with.

But because transgender
might be considered
an older or more established category,

I predicted that maybe people
in each cohort will identify
as transgender at higher levels

than people who identify
as gender-nonconforming.
And so another theory was looking

at the written history by
trans historiographers.
Early history used to suggest

that trans women received
more media coverage
and had more advanced treatment
in terms of medicalized transition
at their disposal than trans men.

But this might have actually
really changed at some point
including in the 1980s and 1990s,

which were a point where
historians remarked

that there was an increase
in visibility for trans men.

So I predict here that
there will be at some point
a convergence of identification patterns.
And so because of this media coverage,
and my theory here is that media coverage

does influence
identification at some point,
my theory was that because the subjects

of the media coverage in
the 1950s and later on

into the late 20th century
were primarily white,
that the people who grew up

and came of age in these
cohorts might also,

there might be higher
identification as trans

among people who are white
then people who are not white.

If we take the hypothesis
that representation

influences the possibilities
available to us,

maybe this will also be
a point of convergence

or maybe there will be a
disparity that continues.
And same for education.
So because transgender as a category
really is associated with queer theory,

perhaps earlier cohorts will
be the more college-educated
compared to now where the media

and the internet are democratizing
identification patterns.

Maybe this will also be
a pattern of convergence.
So what do I find?

Overall, so there was not
a linear relationship here.
I'm presenting in blue
people who identify as transgender,

in red people who identify
as transgender-nonconforming.

The dashed lines are the
95% confidence intervals,

and the dots are the
predicted probabilities.

And statistically, we don't
actually see a very big change

between cohorts born
between 1935 and 1984.
It is actually a pretty,

the only significant rise is
in cohorts born after 1985

and then especially in
cohorts born after 1995.

So there does seem to be
a tipping point of sorts.
It is not a gradual increase.
And so while transgender identity
is significantly more common
than gender-nonconforming identity,

both have reflected this
tipping point increase.
There hasn't been a gradual change for one

and no change or a tipping
point for the other.

Both really correspond
to this tipping point
among people born after 1985.
But one thing that is interesting to me

is that so there was no
information unfortunately

about sex assigned at birth for
gender-nonconforming people.
Because of the way the question was worded

in terms of are you
male-to-female, female-to-male,
there were ways to get

sex assigned at birth and
gender identification.
And one thing that I found here
was a convergence in the trends.

That while numbers were
higher among people
assigned male at birth,
over time we do see a convergence

and so now there are basically
statistically just as likely
to be trans men as there are trans women,
even though in earlier cohorts before 1985

there were more likely to be
trans women than trans men.

Now when we turn to look at
the role of race and ethnicity,
on the left is transgender identification.

On the right is
gender-nonconforming identification.
Kierra did not have a large enough sample

to disaggregate between
Black, and Hispanic,
and Native American, and Asian,
so I used work from the color line

to conceptualize of a
white, non-white difference.
Hopefully in the future

more data will make it
easier to disaggregate,
but I did find this pattern interesting.

I was wrong when I hypothesized
that greater representation
would correspond to greater prevalence.
There's actually been more prevalence

of transgender identity
among non-white people

in all of these earlier cohorts
than among white people.
It is actually only the tipping point
that then makes it a predominantly,

or not predominantly, I
don't want to use that word.
Now in more recent cohorts,

people who are white are
more likely to be transgender
than people who are not white
which calls into question a lot of things
about what representation is doing,

has representation changed,
and is it really leading
to the opening of possibilities?
And here's one finding that I think

has a lot of potential
political significance.

It's actually always been
people who don't go to college

who are more likely to
identify as transgender
than people who do go to college.

So all of this rhetoric
pointed at college professors

and their queer theory are
really working the crowd
and stirring a gender revolution,
unfortunately we are not that successful.
(audience laughs)
So this is I think something
that there's a lot left to unpack here,

but I'm going to move
on to the implications.

So what we're seeing in terms
of sex assigned at birth,

we're seeing a convergence,
a lowered relevance

of sex assigned at birth
to gender possibilities.
It is not a craze.
It is just that sex assigned at birth
is less relevant than it ever has been
in terms of identifying as transgender.

Visibility does not always
translate to growth,

and college attendance
consistently predicts
lower trans identifications.
It's no surprise to anyone to hear

that there are a lot of
barriers to attending college

that being a trans person in
a K through 12 environment
would close the doors towards,
and so it is not the professors.
Something else is going on,

and it doesn't seem to be
the role of education either.

But what are the implications
for civil rights frameworks
in terms of the master's tools?
There have been victories used getting

this essentialist argument
about random distribution.
I think that we can find other types
of civil rights frameworks that work

from things that are
not randomly distributed
like language and religion
that are still protected in some way.
It does not need to be immutable
and randomly distributed to be defended
as part of something we value.

And so that's really
what I want to encourage
people to take away from this

is that there are ways
to argue successfully

for trans rights and
gender self-determination
that find common cause in
religion and language.

Language is something
that people can change,

which might be, it makes
it different from gender.

But I hope that we see here
that there are other frameworks
other than this kind of immutability.

And I also hope that it helps
us to embrace identification,

to look at conditions for the
possibility of trans thriving
and to dream big about a better world

for gender self-determination
for all. Thank you.
(audience applauds)
